items.title: nixos: init LACT module

items.content_html:
This option allows the user to specify a list of extra entries to be added to the end of the grub menu.

Description of changes

I added this new option as boot.loader.grub.extraEntriesAtEnd, This option adds entries at the end of grub, The normal extraEntries option adds entries in the middle of NixOS and NixOS-Generations entry.

I wanted to add shutdown and reboot entries and end, but that old option was never designed to do that, so I created this new option which runs after OS Prober, and after OS Prober adds those entries then from this option entries are taken.

Things done

I added an option with its description.
I added that option in the Perl file, after the line where OS Prober entries are loaded.

My Message

I have never worked with Perl, but I am a student studying software engineering, and I used GitHub Copilot, so it may or may not contain bugs, please check it, I want this option as I am frustrated with the old option and it's arrangement, so please add it.

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This PR moves the existing Prometheus test to just being a Thanos test, whilst adding more test cases specific to Prometheus itself:

  • Alertmanager
  • Federation
  • Pushgateway
  • Remote write

Also adds a alertmanager-webhook-logger package+module so that the Alertmanager test can be end-to-end.

items.title: nixos/radicle: init services

items.content_html:
cc @vunso @hbjydev @claudiiii

Description of changes

This adds a NixOS module for grafana-alloy.

I started from the grafana-agent, one but dropped all settings and
config management whatsoever.

grafana-alloy uses its own Alloy config format (similar to HCL), which
is not really possible to express in Nix.
Simply pointing to a path in `/etc`, and leaving it up to the user to configure
it via `environment.etc` allows the user to arrange config files however
it makes most sense for them.

It also adds a VM test, ensuring it starts up healthy (with empty config),
and adds it to the package passthru.

items.title: nixos/genealogos: init module

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Add module for automatically configuring the Looking Glass client and associated shared memory and/or KVMFR devices for interacting with guest VMs. The steps done by this module are taken from the official installation instructions.

It's worth noting that I don't know much about nor do I use AppArmor beyond knowing that it exists and what it is. I believe that I configured the policy as recommended by the installation instructions, but due to my unfamiliarity with AppArmor paired with the abstractions placed on top by NixOS, I'm not certain and I haven't tested that part specifically.

I added myself as a maintainer for the module, and I'm happy to do that. However, I'm not sure about the etiquette for notifying or roping in the maintainers of the looking-glass-client package. if they would normally be added here as well, I'm happy to put them on the list as well (or instead if preferred).

This is my first module, so please let me know if I'm doing something in a weird way. I wrote this all up initially as an internal module for my own configuration, but thought it might be more broadly useful. :)

Reviewed points
  • module path fits the guidelines
  • module tests succeed on ARCHITECTURE
  • options have appropriate types
  • options have default
  • options have example
  • options have descriptions
  • No unneeded package is added to environment.systemPackages
  • meta.maintainers is set
  • module documentation is declared in meta.doc
Possible improvements

I'm unsure about how to handle the changes needed in qemu.conf for libvirtd. I've opted to have an option named kvmfr.configureDeviceACLs which is disabled by default, but will append to virtualisation.libvirtd.qemu.verbatimConfig when enabled.

Personally, I've never needed to modify qemu.conf aside from this specific instance, so I expect it to be fairly common for someone to enable this option. However, given that it could end up being added after a configuration from somewhere else, and inadvertently overriding those settings, I've chosen to make it disabled by default. I tried to be very clear in the docs, and in the description for the option what exactly it does and when/why you would want to enable it.

If anyone has a better suggestion, I'm all ears.

  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 24.05 Release Notes (or backporting 23.05 and 23.11 Release notes)

    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

items.title: nixos/pixivfe: init

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Continuation of #81135.

The location of the release type is open for discussion, it could go into lib.types instead.

Test with

nix-instantiate --eval -E '(import ./nixos { configuration.system.stateVersion = "20.05"; }).config.system.stateVersion'

Correctly invalid (with lib.trivial.release == "24.11"):

"19", "19.3"
"unstable", "nixos-unstable", "nixos.unstable"
"19.04"
"xy.03"
"25.11"
"20.05"
"21.03"

Correctly valid:

"19.03"
"16.09"
"20.09"
"21.05"
"24.11"

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
    • sandbox = relaxed
    • sandbox = true
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 24.11 Release Notes (or backporting 23.11 and 24.05 Release notes)

    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module

items.title: nixos/version: validate system.stateVersion

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Discovered with Garnix, the checks are executed on push and it is currently impure. This PR makes the Flake pure for nix flake check.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
    • sandbox = relaxed
    • sandbox = true
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 24.11 Release Notes (or backporting 23.11 and 24.05 Release notes)
    • (Package updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is major or breaking
    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
